summary: This document contains an email chain and a Law360 news article discussing Alan Dershowitz's legal motion to disqualify the Boies Schiller Flexner law firm from representing his accuser in a sexual misconduct case. The article details the procedural history, Dershowitz's conflict-of-interest arguments, and the firm's response, all within the broader context of the Jeffrey Epstein scandal.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Prominent attorney and retired professor accused of sexual misconduct by a woman who alleges Jeffrey Epstein "lent her out for sex" to him. He is seeking to disqualify the Boies Schiller law firm from representing his accuser.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Convicted billionaire sex offender at the center of the scandal. The accuser alleges Epstein lent her out for sex to Dershowitz and that Dershowitz played a role in Epstein's human trafficking scheme.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The New York federal judge presiding over the case. She initially refused, then agreed to consider Dershowitz's motion to disqualify the Boies Schiller law firm.

persons.name: Carlos Sires
persons.context: A partner at Boies Schiller who, in 2015, offered to represent Dershowitz in a separate matter. Dershowitz claims he shared confidential strategy with Sires before learning the firm represented his accuser.

persons.name: Arthur L. Aidala
persons.context: Counsel for Alan Dershowitz, from the firm Aidala Bertuna & Kamins PC. He issued a statement expressing gratification that the court would consider Dershowitz's motion.

persons.name: Imran H. Ansari
persons.context: Counsel for Alan Dershowitz, from the firm Aidala Bertuna & Kamins PC. He co-issued a statement with Arthur Aidala.

persons.name: Joshua Schiller
persons.role: Attorney for the Accuser, Partner at Boies Schiller Flexner LLP
persons.context: Attorney representing Dershowitz's accuser. He submitted a letter urging Judge Preska to deny the disqualification request, arguing Dershowitz was attempting to manufacture a conflict to delay the case.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.role: Attorney for the Accuser, Partner at Boies Schiller Flexner LLP
persons.context: Attorney representing Dershowitz's accuser, alongside Joshua Schiller.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: Judge who ruled in February 2019 that Labor Secretary Alex Acosta and other prosecutors mishandled the decade-old Epstein case by signing a non-prosecution agreement without notifying victims.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney who, according to a February 2019 ruling by Judge Marra, mishandled the initial Epstein prosecution by signing a non-prosecution agreement without notifying victims.

persons.name: Andrew Strickler
persons.context: The author of the Law360 news article embedded in the email chain.

connections.description: The accuser alleges Dershowitz was Epstein's attorney and friend and was involved in Epstein's human trafficking scheme. Epstein allegedly "lent her out for sex" to Dershowitz.

In 2015, Sires offered to represent Dershowitz. Dershowitz shared a confidential legal strategy memo with Sires, but no formal attorney-client relationship was established according to Boies Schiller.
Aidala is current legal counsel representing Dershowitz in the motion to disqualify Boies Schiller.

events.title: Sires Offers Representation to Dershowitz
events.description: Boies Schiller partner Carlos Sires offered to represent Alan Dershowitz in a separate Crime Victims Rights Act lawsuit related to Epstein.

events.title: Law360 Article on Disqualification Motion
events.description: Law360 reports that Judge Preska will consider Dershowitz's motion to disqualify Boies Schiller from representing his accuser, after initially removing it for a procedural violation.

events.title: Judge Marra's Ruling on Epstein Prosecution
events.description: U.S. District Judge Kenneth A. Marra ruled that prosecutors, including Alex Acosta, violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not notifying Epstein's victims before signing a 2008 non-prosecution agreement with him.

events.title: Dershowitz Files Disqualification Motion
events.description: Alan Dershowitz filed a motion arguing Boies Schiller Flexner LLP should be disqualified from representing his accuser due to a "severe" conflict of interest stemming from prior contact with partner Carlos Sires.

locations: U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Alan Dershowitz is accused by a woman who alleges Jeffrey Epstein "lent her out for sex" to him and that Dershowitz played a role in Epstein's human trafficking scheme.

Dershowitz moved to disqualify the Boies Schiller law firm from representing his accuser, citing a conflict because he previously shared a confidential legal strategy memo with firm partner Carlos Sires.
Judge Loretta Preska initially removed the disqualification motion for a procedural error but later reinstated it and agreed to consider its merits.
Boies Schiller attorneys argue no attorney-client relationship was ever formed with Dershowitz and that his motion is a "tactical" attempt to delay the case and disrupt their client's representation.

The document references a February 2019 ruling by Judge Kenneth Marra that found Labor Secretary Alex Acosta and other prosecutors mishandled the initial Epstein case by failing to notify victims of a non-prosecution agreement.
